issue.title: Add tests for the repository module

repository.name: bugbug
repository.description: Platform for Machine Learning projects on Software Engineering

issue.body:
- [x] repository.get_revs (#380)
- [x] repository.get_directories (#381)
- [x] repository.download_commits (#379)
- [x] repository.calculate_experiences (#382)
- [x] repository.hg_log (#385)
- [ ] repository._transform (#384)
- [x] repository.get_commits (#383)
- [x] repository.download_component_mapping (#535)

body:
Hi, wanted to work on this. Have a few queries /clarifications, would be great if I can get some guidance.
1. This issue requires tests to be written for get_commits() method in bugbug/repository.py, correct?
2. The tests for bugbug/repository.py have to be written in test/test_repository.py, correct?
3.  So since the get_commits() method is returning the content of the database(?), what are some test cases that are expected to test this method (looking for some example scenarios).

> This issue requires tests to be written for get_commits() method in bugbug/repository.py, correct?

Yes.

> The tests for bugbug/repository.py have to be written in test/test_repository.py, correct?

Yes.

> So since the get_commits() method is returning the content of the database(?), what are some test cases that are expected to test this method (looking for some example scenarios).

You can just add a simple test case that calls the method and asserts that the right commit is returned (you can check that its node property corresponds to the right one).
Tests are using the mock files from tests/fixtures, so in this case tests/fixtures/commits.json.
Thanks for the clarifications, seems pretty straight forward, will be raising a PR soon. Is there any branching strategy that is being followed that I need to know about before making a PR?

> Is there any branching strategy that is being followed that I need to know about before making a PR?

Just the usual workflow on GitHub. You create a fork, a branch in your fork, then create a PR in this repo from your branch in your fork.

Here's what I did:
1. Created a virtual environment, installed the requirements and test-requirements 
2. Copied the bugbug directory into the tests directory
3. Ran pytest

I got an error in the test_repository.py, is that expected output? Should I go ahead and add the tests? Or am I doing something wrong?

You don't need to copy the bugbug directory into the tests directory.
Simply running `python3 -m pytest tests/test_repository.py` should work.

> is that expected output?

If you don't paste the output here, it's going to be hard for me to tell you whether that output is expected :P

![Screenshot from 2019-05-15 22-58-26](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/33370824/57796051-12a95400-7765-11e9-9ebc-88223f6d2218.png)
![Screenshot from 2019-05-15 22-58-39](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/33370824/57796053-12a95400-7765-11e9-967f-29bbca9f6ee2.png)
Added screenshots : ```FileNotFoundError: [Errno 2] No such file or directory: 'hg': 'hg'

/usr/lib/python3.6/subprocess.py:1344: FileNotFoundError
========================================================= 2 passed, 1 error in 0.14 seconds ==========================================================
```

This error comes from trying to call the `/usr/bin/hg` command, with `subprocess.Popen()` but you do not appear to have mercurial installed, which results in the `FileNotFoundError` exception.
You can see this from the line: `self = <subprocess.Popen object>, args = ['hg', 'init', ...]` which is a result of `hglib.init(d)`
@hotdogman is right, installing Mercurial is a requirement for the project.

Haha, yeah finally got it working. I guess a few things can be updated in the documentation like running tests and the Mercurial dependency. I might have missed it, if it is already mentioned somewhere let me know if it is. also opened an PR with a basic test, will add more let me know: #447

Hello Marco,
If this bug is still open and unassigned, mind if I attempt it?
Yes, of course, no need to ask!
I'm having issues downloading the rs_parsepatch module for running test files with pip3. The error tells me it can't be installed since I have python 2.7 but I'm using python 3.6.
@peterchou3788 can you post a log of the command you are running and the result of the command?
Open an issue in the rs-parsepatch repo (https://github.com/mozilla/pyo3-parsepatch) though, as this is not the right place to discuss that.
Is this issue still open? If yes, then can I work on this?
No need to ask, you can work on any issue that has no open PR linked to it.

issue.title: Add tests for get commit function and add additional mock commits

repository.name: bugbug
repository.description: Platform for Machine Learning projects on Software Engineering

issue.body:
- Add tests for get commit function 
- Add additional mock commit in test fixtures to test parameters in get commit
- Closes #383
